name: Lee Shurtleff
additionalNotes: Confirmed re-election bid; significant incumbency advantage.
bio: Lee Shurtleff is a veteran legislator serving as the incumbent County Legislator for District 9, focusing on public safety and infrastructure improvements in rural communities.

name: Michael J. Murphy
additionalNotes: Endorsed across party lines; filed candidacy.
bio: Michael J. Murphy has been the Mayor of Dryden Village since 2017 and previously served as a Village Trustee. Under his leadership, major grants for water/sewer upgrades and downtown redevelopment were secured.

name: Peter Walsh
additionalNotes: Filed for re-election; cross-endorsed by major parties.
bio: Peter Walsh is an incumbent Town Justice, serving since 2019 with a focus on efficient case management and alternative sentencing for low-level offenses.

name: Leonardo Vargas-Méndez
additionalNotes: Running for re-election.
bio: Leonardo Vargas-Méndez is an incumbent Town Board member and Conservation Board Chair, with a background as a retired Cornell administrator and expertise in community planning.

name: Jason Leifer
additionalNotes: Running unopposed per party filings.
bio: Jason Leifer is the incumbent Town Supervisor, a local attorney who has led projects like Dryden Fiber. First elected in 2015, he focuses on broadband expansion and renewable energy initiatives.

name: Rick Young
additionalNotes: Filed for re-election; expected to appear on multiple ballot lines.
bio: Rick Young is the incumbent Highway/DPW Superintendent, overseeing road maintenance and public works with decades of experience in Dryden.

name: Dan Wakeman
additionalNotes: Nominated at Republican caucus; his second campaign in two years.
bio: Dan Wakeman is a longtime public servant and Village Trustee from Dryden, running for County Legislator for the redrawn district that includes Dryden.

name: Jason L. Dickinson
additionalNotes: Unanimously renominated by Democrats; filed candidacy.
bio: Jason L. Dickinson has served as a Village Trustee since 2021 and is a high school teacher focused on youth programs, park improvements, and downtown revitalization.

name: Allison 'Allie' Buck
additionalNotes: Nominated at Dem caucus; filed candidacy.
bio: Allison 'Allie' Buck, a young professional and Cornell employee, was appointed to fill a board vacancy and is now running for her first full term as Village Trustee.

name: Trevor Cross
policies: Affordable Housing: Wants to expand housing options and lower costs.
Community Engagement: Advocates for fresh perspectives in local government.
bio: Trevor Cross is a Cornell postdoctoral researcher and housing advocate, passionate about affordable housing and community development. Though he originally sought the Democratic nomination, he ran independently after Murphy was selected.

name: Carolyn Greenwald
additionalNotes: Seeking election as a Trustee for the Village of Lansing.
bio: Carolyn Greenwald is running for Village Trustee in Lansing, NY. She has been an active community member and advocate for sustainable development and local governance transparency.

name: Gregory Mezey
additionalNotes: Running for re-election; endorsed by local Democrats.
bio: Gregory Mezey is the incumbent County Legislator for District 13, known for his work on affordable housing, smart land use, and economic development as the Legislature Vice-Chair.

name: Thomas C. 'Tom' Corey
additionalNotes: Nominated at Republican caucus; his second campaign in two years.
bio: Thomas C. 'Tom' Corey is a local businessman, U.S. Army veteran, and member of the Village Zoning Board. He previously ran for Town Supervisor in 2023 and is now challenging for Village Mayor.

name: David S. Bravo-Cullen
additionalNotes: Filed via Republican caucus; aligned with Corey's platform.
bio: David S. Bravo-Cullen is a Dryden native and contractor making his first run for office after serving as an alternate on the village Planning Board.

name: Ronny Hardaway
additionalNotes: Running for re-election as Village Mayor of Lansing.
bio: Ronny Hardaway is the incumbent Mayor of Lansing, NY. He has been involved in local governance, focusing on infrastructure development and fiscal responsibility.

name: Johnny Appleseed
bio: Test Bio is here

name: Brittany Kinser
policies: Prioritize core curriculum (reading, writing, math, science)
Increase transparency in school funding and spending
Restore high academic standards for students
Support school choice options for families
Modernize school funding formula to increase state funding share
additionalNotes: Kinser’s platform emphasizes refocusing on core academic subjects (reading, writing, math, science) and raising academic standards on the belief that students will meet higher expectations. She calls for greater transparency in education funding to ensure more resources reach classrooms and teachers instead of administrative overhead. Kinser supports expanding school choice, positioning the Department of Public Instruction as a resource for parents seeking the best educational environment for their children. She also advocates updating the school funding formula to increase the state's share of K-12 funding and direct more dollars into classrooms. Though not affiliated with a political party, her stance has resonated with conservatives — evidenced by Republican praise post-primary. As of mid-March 2025, her campaign had raised over $300,000 (with about $163,000 spent). Her opponent has attempted to cast her background as a lobbyist in a negative light during the campaign.
bio: Brittany Kinser is an education consultant, former special education teacher, and nonprofit executive running for Wisconsin State Superintendent of Public Instruction. She advanced from the February 18, 2025 primary with 35.3% of the vote, qualifying for the general election against incumbent Jill Underly. Although the race is officially nonpartisan, Kinser has drawn praise from Republican leaders who labeled her a 'common-sense' candidate for the role after the primary. Her career includes teaching special education in Chicago Public Schools, serving as principal of a Milwaukee charter school, and leading the education nonprofit City Forward Collective. She also co-founded an initiative called 95 Wisconsin to improve literacy rates among children statewide.

name: Jill Underly
policies: Defended lowering of state testing standards as reflecting actual learning levels
Advocates for increased state funding and resources for public schools
Supports teacher apprenticeship programs to improve recruitment and retention
Emphasizes literacy, career education, and student mental health initiatives
Opposes expansion of private school vouchers, focusing on public school support
Prioritizes educational equity and inclusion (addressing achievement gaps, supporting LGBTQ+ students)
additionalNotes: Underly’s tenure has been marked by significant policy decisions. She supported lowering state standardized test benchmarks, a move she argued would provide a more realistic measure of student learning (though critics contend it lowers expectations). She has consistently advocated for increased state investment in public schools and spearheaded efforts to address teacher shortages through apprenticeship and training programs. Underly highlights improvements under her leadership, such as Wisconsin achieving its highest-ever high school graduation rate, passing a bipartisan literacy bill, and making historic investments in student mental health services. She has publicly committed to supporting marginalized groups — acknowledging the achievement gap between Black and white students, defending the rights of LGBTQ+ students, and opposing cuts to federal education funding. Underly also stands against expanding private school voucher programs, emphasizing the importance of strengthening public education. In her initial 2021 race, she was endorsed by numerous Democratic officials (and even a retired Republican state senator), reflecting broad support. As of mid-March 2025, her re-election campaign had raised around $82,000 (with roughly $38,000 spent).
bio: Jill Underly is the incumbent Wisconsin State Superintendent of Public Instruction, first elected in 2021. She has a long career in education, including serving as an assistant director at the Department of Public Instruction and as the superintendent of the Pecatonica Area School District. Underly holds a doctorate in educational leadership and multiple master's degrees, and she began her career as a high school social studies teacher. As state superintendent, she has overseen initiatives to increase school funding, improve literacy and career education, and support teacher development. Underly is running for re-election in 2025, emphasizing her experience and record leading Wisconsin’s public schools.

name: Brad Schimel
policies: Pro-life stance, supports Wisconsin's 1849 abortion ban
Tough-on-crime approach, advocating for victims' rights and supporting law enforcement
Favors limited government regulation (opposed the Affordable Care Act and certain environmental regulations)
Strong supporter of Second Amendment gun rights
Supports Act 10's limits on public unions and backs voter ID laws; defended Republican-drawn redistricting maps
additionalNotes: Schimel’s judicial philosophy aligns with conservative principles. He is staunchly pro-life and has stated that Wisconsin’s 1849 law banning abortion should be upheld. In criminal justice, he has advocated for greater involvement of crime victims in legal proceedings and emphasizes holding offenders accountable. As Attorney General, Schimel fought to curtail regulatory oversight by agencies like the EPA and Wisconsin DNR, and he co-led a multi-state lawsuit to overturn the Affordable Care Act. He is a strong supporter of gun rights and opposed efforts to impose stricter regulations on coal-fired power plants. Schimel also defends Act 10 (the 2011 law that limited public-sector collective bargaining) and has supported voter ID requirements while attempting to limit early voting. In redistricting matters, he helped defend legislative maps drawn by Republicans. Schimel was appointed to the bench by then-Governor Scott Walker, and his campaign has drawn backing from many Republican-aligned groups. Notably, significant outside money has poured into this race — including contributions linked to Elon Musk — underscoring the high stakes of this Supreme Court election.
bio: Brad Schimel is a Waukesha County Circuit Court Judge and former Wisconsin Attorney General running for a seat on the Wisconsin Supreme Court. Schimel served as the state Attorney General from 2015 to 2019 and was appointed to the circuit court in 2019. With decades of legal experience, he portrays his career as one focused on defending victims and supporting law enforcement. Schimel is generally regarded as a conservative candidate; while the Supreme Court race is nonpartisan, he has significant Republican support. His campaign emphasizes restoring public confidence in the court’s fairness and impartiality, and this election could potentially shift the court’s ideological balance.

name: Susan Crawford
policies: Pro-choice stance; supports women's access to reproductive healthcare and opposed abortion restrictions
Supports campaign finance reform and strong regulations on money in politics
Advocates for restorative justice and diversion programs in the criminal justice system
Strong supporter of labor unions and workers’ rights
Favors nonpartisan redistricting and opposes strict voter ID laws (prefers more inclusive voter verification methods)
additionalNotes: Throughout her career, Crawford has championed progressive causes and civil rights. She has been an advocate for women’s rights and reproductive freedom, notably representing Planned Parenthood in challenging Wisconsin’s abortion restrictions. She supports robust campaign finance regulations to limit the influence of money in judicial elections and government. In criminal justice, Crawford emphasizes rehabilitation by supporting restorative justice initiatives and diversion programs over strict incarceration. She has a history of backing labor unions and has represented union interests, reflecting her commitment to workers’ rights. Crawford also advocates for nonpartisan redistricting to prevent gerrymandering and has opposed strict voter ID laws, suggesting alternative methods to verify voters without disenfranchising eligible citizens. Raised in Chippewa Falls, Wisconsin, Crawford highlights her deep roots in the state and dedication to upholding the Wisconsin Constitution’s protections. This Supreme Court race is critical; her election would help maintain the court’s current liberal majority.
bio: Susan Crawford is a Dane County Circuit Court Judge and a former chief legal counsel to Governor Jim Doyle, running for a seat on the Wisconsin Supreme Court. She was appointed to the Dane County bench in 2018 and has a broad background in public service and law, including experience as an assistant attorney general and as a partner at a law firm handling civil litigation. Crawford holds a bachelor's degree from Lawrence University and a J.D. from the University of Iowa College of Law. She is widely regarded as a liberal candidate in this nonpartisan race, endorsed by the Democratic Party of Wisconsin and all four sitting liberal justices of the state Supreme Court. Crawford's campaign centers on protecting fundamental rights and ensuring fair, impartial justice for all Wisconsinites.

name: John Remington
policies: Applies a commonsense judicial philosophy, balancing human factors with legal complexities
Extensive civil litigation experience informs his decision-making on the bench
Committed to impartial and fair application of the law in all cases
additionalNotes: As a judge, Remington is described as taking a "commonsense" approach to the law, striving to balance human considerations with the complexities of legal issues. He has not publicly outlined specific campaign positions (having not completed the Ballotpedia candidate survey), which is typical for a nonpartisan judicial candidate. His professional background in civil litigation gave him experience representing healthcare providers, financial institutions, and businesses in complex cases, experience he brings to his work on the bench. Remington’s appointment by a Democratic governor and the cancellation of a primary election indicate he faced no initial opposition for the seat. He aims to continue serving Milwaukee County with fairness and objectivity.
position: Milwaukee County Circuit Court Judge - Branch 6
bio: John Remington is the incumbent judge for Branch 6 of the Milwaukee County Circuit Court. He was appointed to this seat by Governor Tony Evers in May 2024 and is running for a full six-year term in 2025. Remington previously spent 16 years as a partner at the law firm Quarles & Brady LLP, specializing in commercial litigation (including cases involving non-compete agreements and unfair competition). He earned his undergraduate degree from the University of Wisconsin–Madison and his J.D. from Washington University School of Law in St. Louis. Remington entered the 2025 general election without a primary, as no other candidate filed to run against him.

name: David Swanson
policies: Over a decade of judicial experience with a focus on fair, consistent application of the law
Handled cases involving complex issues (e.g., involuntary medication in criminal proceedings)
Maintains a nonpartisan, impartial stance without political agenda
additionalNotes: Judge Swanson has over a decade of experience on the Milwaukee County bench. While he has not publicized a campaign platform (and did not complete the 2025 candidate survey), his tenure has involved presiding over a broad range of cases. Court records note his involvement in cases concerning involuntary medication orders, reflecting his engagement with complex issues at the intersection of mental health and law. As a nonpartisan judicial candidate, Swanson focuses on maintaining a fair and impartial courtroom rather than on political issues. His long-standing service and the lack of recent opposition suggest a strong level of community and professional confidence in his performance.
position: Milwaukee County Circuit Court Judge - Branch 11
bio: David "Dave" Swanson is the incumbent judge for Branch 11 of the Milwaukee County Circuit Court, a position he has held since 2013. He initially won the seat unopposed and was subsequently re-elected in 2019. Swanson earned his B.A. from Northwestern University and his J.D. from the University of Michigan Law School. Before joining the bench, he practiced law at the firm Whyte Hirschboeck Dudek S.C. He is seeking another six-year term in 2025; the primary for this race was canceled, indicating he faced no challenger going into the general election.

name: William S. Pocan
policies: Long-serving judge with an emphasis on impartial application of the law
Issued notable rulings (e.g., a 2013 decision on utility disconnections under Chapter 128)
Provides administrative leadership as Deputy Chief Judge for Milwaukee County's courts
additionalNotes: Over his long tenure on the circuit court, Judge Pocan has presided over a wide array of cases. While he has not announced any campaign platform (as is typical for a sitting judge), his record includes decisions such as a 2013 ruling clarifying how utility companies handle Chapter 128 debt relief petitions — demonstrating his engagement with consumer protection and financial law issues. Pocan’s role as Deputy Chief Judge involves administrative oversight of Milwaukee County’s courts, reflecting the esteem he holds among his peers. Known for a steady and impartial approach, Pocan has historically run unopposed, indicating he is well-regarded in the community. His attempted elevation to the federal judiciary in 2021 shows that his expertise was recognized at the national level, even though the appointment did not ultimately go through.
position: Milwaukee County Circuit Court Judge - Branch 26
bio: William S. Pocan is the incumbent judge for Branch 26 of the Milwaukee County Circuit Court and currently serves as the Deputy Chief Judge of Wisconsin’s First Judicial District (Milwaukee County). He was appointed to the bench in 2006 by Governor Jim Doyle and has been re-elected without opposition in 2007, 2013, and 2019. Pocan earned his bachelor's degree from the University of Wisconsin–Parkside and his J.D. from the University of Wisconsin Law School. Before becoming a judge, he worked in private legal practice. In 2021, Pocan was nominated for a federal judgeship by President Joe Biden, although that nomination was later withdrawn due to political opposition.

name: Laura A. Crivello
policies: Adheres to a conservative, strict interpretation judicial philosophy (no legislating from the bench)
24-year career as a prosecutor informs her perspective on criminal justice
Focuses on impartial application of the law without pursuing a personal agenda
additionalNotes: Judge Crivello believes that the role of a judge is to interpret the Constitution and laws as written, rather than to legislate from the bench or advance a personal agenda. This principle aligns with a conservative judicial philosophy emphasizing impartiality and restraint. While she has not outlined specific campaign issues (consistent with the nonpartisan nature of judicial elections), her record reflects a tough-on-crime perspective shaped by decades in law enforcement. In 2017, Crivello was honored with a 'Women in the Law' award by the Wisconsin Law Journal, highlighting her impact in the legal field. Appointed by a Republican governor and openly identifying her conservative approach, Crivello is focused on upholding traditional interpretations of the law. Having retained her seat without opposition in the past, she heads into the 2025 election with a track record of stability and respect in her role.
position: Milwaukee County Circuit Court Judge - Branch 36
bio: Laura A. Crivello is the incumbent judge for Branch 36 of the Milwaukee County Circuit Court, serving since her appointment in 2018 by Governor Scott Walker. She earned her undergraduate degree from the University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee and her J.D. from Marquette University Law School. Prior to becoming a judge, Crivello spent 24 years as a prosecutor in the Milwaukee County District Attorney’s Office, focusing on cases involving drug and gang-related offenses. She ran unopposed for election to the bench in 2019 and is seeking re-election in 2025. Crivello’s judicial approach is influenced by her extensive prosecutorial background and a self-described conservative philosophy on the bench.

name: Danielle L. Shelton
policies: Aims to create a more equitable court system that treats all parties with dignity
Considers the real-world consequences of rulings to avoid unjust outcomes
Background in public interest law shapes her focus on fairness and access to justice
additionalNotes: Judge Shelton has emphasized making the court system more equitable and accessible. She often speaks about the need for judges to consider the broader impact of their decisions on people’s lives, striving to prevent unjust outcomes. In line with the nonpartisan nature of her role, Shelton does not campaign on specific political issues, but her comments and career indicate a focus on fairness, dignity, and respect in the courtroom. Her prior work as a public interest lawyer involved advocating for underrepresented communities, which informs her perspective on the bench. In one notable case, Shelton ruled against a county sheriff’s department policy of deleting interrogation recordings, demonstrating her concern for due process and transparency. Her initial election in 2019 was driven by community support for change on the bench, and she continues to draw on her experience as a veteran, attorney, and community advocate in her judicial service.
position: Milwaukee County Circuit Court Judge - Branch 40
bio: Danielle L. Shelton is the incumbent judge for Branch 40 of the Milwaukee County Circuit Court. She won her seat in April 2019, when she defeated the sitting judge in that election, and assumed office on August 1, 2019. Shelton is a former public interest attorney, a background that reflects her commitment to serving the community and advocating for fairness. She earned her undergraduate degree from the University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee and her J.D. from Marquette University Law School. As a judge, Shelton has stressed the importance of ensuring the court system is fair and humane to all participants. She is running for re-election in 2025.

name: Lena C. Taylor
policies: Prioritized education funding and economic justice measures during her legislative career
Supported criminal justice reforms (e.g., independent investigations for police-involved deaths, flexibility in sentencing for non-violent offenses)
Opposed efforts to limit labor rights (voted against Act 10's restrictions on public unions)
Advocates for fair, representative judicial system responsive to the community
Addresses social determinants of justice (economic, health, and safety disparities) through community engagement
additionalNotes: In her legislative career, Taylor was a strong advocate for education and economic justice, pushing for school funding and foreclosure relief measures to help her constituents. She also championed criminal justice reforms; for example, she supported the creation of a process for independent investigations into police-involved deaths and sought to give judges more discretion in handling driver’s license suspensions for drug offenses. Taylor was a vocal opponent of 2011’s Act 10, siding with public workers against the rollback of collective bargaining rights. She has long promoted fair redistricting practices and was an outspoken critic of partisan gerrymandering. Now, as a judge, Taylor emphasizes a justice system that is responsive and representative of the community it serves. She often highlights the importance of addressing underlying social factors — such as economic, health, and safety disparities — that affect justice and outcomes in Milwaukee. A Democrat by affiliation, Taylor brings a wealth of public service experience to her role on the bench. The primary for her 2025 judicial race was canceled, indicating she did not face a challenger before the general election.
position: Milwaukee County Circuit Court Judge - Branch 41
bio: Lena C. Taylor is the incumbent judge for Branch 41 of the Milwaukee County Circuit Court, appointed to the position in January 2024. She is well known as a former Wisconsin state legislator, having served five terms as a State Senator (and earlier as a State Assembly member) representing Milwaukee’s 4th District. During her legislative tenure, Taylor made history as the first African American woman to co-chair the state’s Joint Committee on Finance and as the first African American to chair the Senate Judiciary Committee. She earned her law degree from Southern Illinois University and worked as a public defender before entering politics. After nearly two decades in the legislature, Taylor joined the judiciary and is now running to retain her seat in the 2025 election.

name: Valarie A. Hill
policies: Known for a strict, no-nonsense courtroom demeanor
Focused on enforcing municipal laws and maintaining courtroom order
No stated political platform, emphasizing judicial impartiality
additionalNotes: Throughout her tenure, Judge Hill has been responsible for adjudicating Milwaukee’s municipal ordinance violations, ranging from traffic offenses to quality-of-life infractions. She has not outlined any campaign platform (common for a judicial race), instead pointing to her record of experience and service. Hill is often noted for her tough courtroom demeanor; observers have described her approach as caustic at times, reflecting a strict stance on personal responsibility and decorum in her court. Despite this stern reputation, she has consistently secured re-election, including an uncontested race in 2021. The upcoming 2025 election originally drew interest from potential challengers, but the primary was canceled, suggesting that Hill will effectively run unopposed. With her extensive experience and deep knowledge of Milwaukee’s municipal court system, Hill remains a prominent figure in the city’s judiciary.
bio: Judge Valarie A. Hill is the long-time incumbent for Branch 1 of the Milwaukee Municipal Court. She was first elected in 2004 and has served in this city-level judicial position for over twenty years. Prior to becoming a municipal judge, Hill worked as a Milwaukee County judicial court commissioner and as a public defender. She earned her undergraduate degree from The Ohio State University and her J.D. from the University of Akron School of Law. Hill has a reputation for being a firm and direct presence on the bench, and she is seeking another term in the April 2025 election.

name: Chokwe Antar Lumumba
additionalNotes: Lumumba qualified for re-election just before the deadline on January 31, 2025. In November 2024, he was indicted by a federal grand jury on bribery and related charges, accused of accepting bribes for favors related to real estate development. He has denied wrongdoing and stated he does not plan to resign. Questions were raised about the timely filing of his campaign finance reports.
bio: Chokwe Antar Lumumba is an American attorney and politician serving as the 53rd mayor of Jackson since July 3, 2017. He is the son of former mayor Chokwe Lumumba. He holds a BA from Tuskegee University and a JD from Texas Southern University. He was re-elected in 2021. He identifies as a progressive and socialist.

Has worked as a consultant, for the Hinds County Sheriff Dept., MS Dept of Human Services (Early Detection Fraud Prevention), as a teacher for Jackson Public Schools, and as an Insurance Fraud Investigator. Member of various county official associations.

He faces challengers in the Democratic primary, and the winner will face him and any other Independent candidates in the June 3, 2025 general election.
bio: Ashby Foote is the incumbent council member for Ward 1, first elected in a 2014 special election. He is the founder of Vector Money Management, a financial services company. He graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1974 and holds an MBA from Southern Methodist University. His background is primarily in finance.

She won the seat after the previous councilwoman resigned following a guilty plea to federal bribery charges. Filed required campaign finance reports ahead of the 2025 election cycle.

additionalNotes: This is his second campaign for the Ward 2 City Council seat. His platform emphasizes his long residency in the ward and his military background. Policies listed are from his 2024 campaign.
bio: A 31-year veteran of the military who retired in 2023. He has been a resident of Jackson's Ward 2 for over 48 years, living in the Ashley Acres neighborhood. He previously ran for the Ward 2 seat in the October 2024 special election, losing in the run-off to Tina Clay.

name: Kenneth I. Stokes
additionalNotes: Known for over 30 years of leading the city's Martin Luther King, Jr. celebration. He is running unopposed in the Democratic primary scheduled for April 1, 2025. Has had public disagreements with the mayoral administration regarding city contracts and governance.
bio: Born and raised in Jackson, Mississippi, Kenneth I. Stokes is a graduate of Lanier High School and Jackson State University. He earned a Juris Doctorate from Thurgood Marshall School of Law at Texas Southern University. Stokes holds the distinction of being the first African American graduate of Jackson Public Schools to serve on the Jackson City Council and is the longest-serving African American elected official in the city's government. His tenure began in 1989, spanning six terms. He also served as Hinds County Supervisor for District Five from 2012 to 2015 before being re-elected to the City Council in a special election.

name: Marques T. Jackson
additionalNotes: Qualified as an Independent candidate. As per election rules, Independent candidates do not participate in the primary election but will appear on the General Election ballot on June 3, 2025, challenging the primary winner.

name: Brian C. Grizzell

He is running for a full term in the 2025 election cycle. He presented a resolution honoring Jackson State University's Sonic Boom of the South band in July 2024.
bio: Brian Grizzell is the incumbent council member for Ward 4, having held the seat since a special election in early 2023 (though some sources state July 1, 2021, likely referring to a previous term or initial election before a runoff/special election confirmation). He is a former Jackson Public Schools educator. He announced his bid for reelection on January 1, 2025.

name: Vernon W. Hartley

bio: Vernon W. Hartley is the current City Council Member representing Ward 5 in Jackson, Mississippi. He assumed office on July 1, 2021, after defeating the three-term incumbent Charles Tillman in a Democratic primary runoff election. His current term ends on July 1, 2025. He is running for re-election in the 2025 municipal elections.

name: Charles Alexander
additionalNotes: Alexander is challenging the incumbent, Vernon W. Hartley, in the Democratic primary scheduled for April 1, 2025.
bio: Charles Alexander is running as a challenger for the Jackson City Council Ward 5 seat in the 2025 Democratic primary.

additionalNotes: Emon D. Thompson Sr. is running in the Democratic primary for Jackson City Council Ward 6. The incumbent, Aaron Banks, is not seeking re-election following federal charges. Ward 6 is guaranteed new representation after this election.

The Mooreland Public Schools website previously listed Tyson Miller as holding Seat 5 with a term expiring in 2025, but official filing records confirm Jason Louthan filed for this seat for the upcoming term.

position: Incumbent, Oklahoma City Public Schools Board Member, District 2
bio: Lori Bowman is the incumbent board member for District 2 of the Oklahoma City Public Schools. She won re-election for the term starting after the April 1, 2025 election date because no other candidates filed for the seat. The primary and general elections for this seat were canceled.

name: Carole Thompson
additionalNotes: Won election automatically as the sole candidate who filed for the District 1 seat. Her next term begins after the certification of the April 1, 2025 election results.
position: Incumbent, Oklahoma City Public Schools Board Member, District 1
bio: Carole Thompson is the incumbent board member for District 1 of the Oklahoma City Public Schools. She won re-election for the term starting after the April 1, 2025 election date because no other candidates filed for the seat. The primary and general elections for this seat were canceled.

name: Steve Nguyen
additionalNotes: Won election automatically as the sole candidate who filed for the Zone 5 seat.
position: Candidate for Union Public Schools Board Member, Zone 5
bio: Steve Nguyen filed for the Zone 5 seat on the Union Public Schools school board. As the only candidate to file, the primary election scheduled for February 11, 2025, and the general election scheduled for April 1, 2025, were both canceled. He won the election without appearing on the ballot.

name: Camal Pennington
additionalNotes: Led the four-way primary election on February 11, 2025, securing 45.49% of the vote, advancing him to the April 1 runoff.
position: Ward 7 Planning Commissioner, Executive Director of It's My Community Initiative
bio: Camal Pennington is a native of northeast Oklahoma City. He holds a bachelor's degree in political science from Oklahoma City University, where he was a Clara Luper scholar, and attended the University of Oklahoma College of Law. His previous roles include Executive Director of Annual Giving and Director of Admissions at the OU College of Law. Currently, he serves as the Executive Director for It's My Community Initiative, a nonprofit organization dedicated to supporting financially vulnerable families. He also represents Ward 7 on the Oklahoma City Planning Commission.

name: John A. Pettis, Jr.
additionalNotes: Finished second in the February 11, 2025, primary election with 30.24% of the vote, advancing to the April 1 runoff. He previously resigned from the Ward 7 council seat in 2018 amid felony charges related to embezzlement and failure to file state tax returns between 2009 and 2017.
position: Former Ward 7 City Councilman, Associate Minister
bio: John A. Pettis, Jr. previously served as the City Council member representing Ward 7. He is currently an associate minister at Faith, Hope, and Love Missionary Baptist Church. During his previous tenure, he served on the Northeast Renaissance TIF Review Committee and the OKC Innovation District TIF STEM Education and Workforce Development Committee.

name: Henry Laurence Heikkila
party: Nonpartisan (Municipal elections in Norman are nonpartisan, though Heikkila identifies as a conservative)
additionalNotes: Heikkila unseated incumbent Breea Clark in the 2022 mayoral runoff election. He was backed by Norman's Fraternal Order of Police in that election. He faced criticism during his term regarding disagreements about a homeless shelter and a proposed TIF district. He supported SB 484, a state bill that would limit municipal spending on homeless services.
bio: Larry Heikkila was elected Mayor of Norman in 2022, defeating the previous incumbent. Before becoming mayor, he worked for the City of Norman for 17 years, serving as Street Supervisor, Personnel Analyst, and Safety Manager, retiring in 2014. He also retired in 2010 after 26 years in the U.S. Navy, serving in the Submarine Force and as a US Navy Seabee, retiring as Command Master Chief. He holds a Bachelor of Science with Honors in Business Management from the University of Phoenix and is a graduate of the U.S. Navy Senior Enlisted Academy. He previously served on Cleveland County boards including the Excise Board, Equalization Board, and Tax Roll Correction Board. He is also an ordained Deacon and Chaplain.

name: Bob Thompson
party: Nonpartisan (Municipal elections in Norman are nonpartisan)
additionalNotes: Bob Thompson ran for Mayor in the 2022 election cycle as well, participating in the primary but not advancing to the runoff. He is often referred to as "Midway Bob Thompson" due to his ownership of Midway Deli.
position: Business Owner (Midway Deli), Former Norman City Councilmember
bio: Bob Thompson is a long-time Norman resident (over 40 years) and the owner of Midway Deli. He previously served on the Norman City Council representing Ward 1 from 2005 to 2009. He also chaired the Norman Charter Review Commission. He was inducted into the Oklahoma Housing Hall of Fame in 2016.

name: Mark A. Nash
additionalNotes: Nash led the primary election on February 11, 2025, with 34.89% of the vote. He opposed the general obligation bond tri-proposal that voters rejected in November 2024. He argues his financial background and committee participation make him the better candidate.
bio: Mark Nash is a financial professional with decades of experience. He previously served for 12 years on the Edmond Economic Development Authority Board of Trustees. He also worked in state government for a decade as an auditor and financial analyst, eventually becoming the director of finance for the Oklahoma Department of Public Safety. He has served on the editorial board of the defunct Edmond Sun and currently chairs the editorial board for The Edmond Way. He has also served with the Edmond Public Schools Foundation.

name: Tom Robins
additionalNotes: Robins received 34.25% of the vote in the February 11, 2025 primary, trailing Mark Nash by 45 votes. He highlights his council record, including a 'No' vote on increasing water rates in September 2023 and support for the Uncommon Ground Sculpture Park. He has received endorsements from the Edmond branches of the Fraternal Order of Police and International Association of Firefighters, as well as Brian Shellem (who ran against the incumbent mayor in 2023). He has pledged to run a positive campaign without attack ads.
bio: Tom Robins served as the Ward 1 Councilman for the City of Edmond. He was elected in 2023 and vacated the seat in November 2024 to run for mayor, as required by the city charter. His term would have run until May 2027.

name: Jason Lowe
additionalNotes: Won the Democratic primary on February 11, 2025. The special election was called following the resignation of Carrie Blumert.
bio: Jason Lowe is an Oklahoma State Representative, first elected in 2016, representing District 97. He works as a criminal defense attorney. His experience includes serving on the House Judiciary Committee.

bio: Dave Donelson is the incumbent representing District 1. He is a former U.S. Army Green Beret and Iraq War veteran. After retiring from the Army in 2010, he worked as a physician assistant and directed a men's health center. He moved to Colorado Springs 34 years ago. He currently serves as the Chair of the Board of Directors of Colorado Springs Utilities and President of the El Paso County Board of Health. He has also served on various committees including PPRTA, PPACG, LART, Stormwater, Audit, and Independent Ethics.
